repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Economic Governance and Poverty
            Reduction Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Economic Governance and
            Poverty Reduction Credit Project (EGPRC) for Ghana were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was moderate; Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory; borrower performance was satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned includes: improving harmonized frameworks.
            Importance of announcement or credibility effects.
            Announcement of the approval of an operation like EGPRC did
            help in stabilizing exchange rate. It helped through (i) the
            replenishment of foreign reserves and (ii) that the Bank and
            International Monetary Fund (IMF) macro monitoring and
            support to structural reform will help addressing some of
            the causes of the rapid depreciation. Need for realistic
            time framework and sequencing. While determining the prior
            actions to be achieved, there is a need on the part of the
            Bank and the Government to be realistic about the time
            framework and the sequencing within which the deliverables
            can be achieved. Trade-off between responsiveness to crisis
            and quality at entry. The quality at entry is likely to
            suffer in a situation such as the once faced by the Bank
            during the preparation of the EGPRC, when it had to respond
            to the macroeconomic crisis on an emergency basis.
            Importance of Civil Society Organizations (CSOs), think
            tanks, trade unions and other organized structures. As the
            Government by itself is unlikely to create an external
            accountability mechanism, the Bank can play a major role for
            creating and strengthening it by involving CSOs, think
            tanks, trade unions and other organized structures.

repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Economic Governance and Poverty
            Reduction Credit Program

abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic Governance and Poverty
            Reduction Credit (EGPRC) Program  for Ghana aims to support
            the authorities' efforts, in the midst of the current
            global crisis, to bring their fiscal stance to a sound and
            sustainable track and protect the development objectives set
            in Ghana's Second Growth and Poverty Reduction Strategy
            (GPRS II) for the period 2006-2009. The GPRS II emphasizes
            the centrality of private-led growth to reduce poverty,
            along with human development and governance efforts to
            promote equity. While EGPRC will translate primarily into
            funding for the GPRS II implementation, particular attention
            is given to: (i) restoring budgetary discipline; and (ii)
            tackling long-standing public sector and energy issues. The
            Development Policy Operation (DPO) is part of a program of
            support to Ghana during FY09 that currently implies a 27
            percent front-loading of International Development
            Association (IDA) assistance. This operation will be
            complemented by a sector (natural resources) development
            policy operation (US$l0 million), and two investment
            projects in transport (US$225 million) and rural water
            (US$15 million). Other operations being prepared for FY10
            include an International Bank for Reconstruction and
            Development (IBRD) enclave for the gas sector, a sector
            development policy operation (agriculture), support for the
            development of safety nets, a project in support of the
            water and sanitation sectors, and a joint initiative with
            partners to support public sector reforms and capacity development.
